title: Parse Error in ASN1.value when attempting to access CertificateSigningRequest.extension.
body:
If you're filing a bug (as opposed to a feature request), please try the
following things:

* Check the FAQ to see if your issue is covered there:
  https://cryptography.io/en/latest/faq.html
* Upgrade to the latest version of ``setuptools`` and ``pip``
* Make sure you're on a supported version of OpenSSL
* Try with the latest version of ``cryptography``
* Be sure you have the required compilers (both a C compiler and Rust)
  installed if you aren't using the binary wheels.

If none of that works, please make sure to include the following information in
your bug report:

* Versions of Python, ``cryptography``, ``cffi``, ``pip``, and ``setuptools``
  you're using
* How you installed ``cryptography``
* Clear steps for reproducing your bug

Please do not report security issues on Github! Follow the instructions in our
documentation for reporting security issues:
https://cryptography.io/en/latest/security.htm

Currently when attemtping to access certificatesigningrequest.extension, we get 

ParseError: Error in ASN.1 parsing {kind: ShortData}

However, according to documenation we expect to see - the Extensions in their entirety.

The reason for the fix here:

1. For a script/function that would vet the CSR's extensions to see which ones should be included and which ones should not, we would need to be able to parse the extensions. Eg. CSR has been signed requesting for ServerAuth KeyUsage, or data_encipherment. But the CA, would want to verify if that is truly needed or not, and would reject the CSR if not correct.
2. Also, to more align with the documenation that would return the extensions object.

Prior related issues; #6872 

In #6872 the Certificate.extensions was not accessible due to the parse error. However, in this case, we have a valid scenario where we may need to access the extensions for the CertificateSigningRequest, even if for tallying the extensions themselves. For example, when we get a csr from an external entity, and we would want to tally the extensions after loading it into the python program using load_csr
